content.title: Understanding the 3-Plate System
content.content:
Safety note: This lesson is for conceptual learning on training rigs. Never open or work on real ceiling roses unless the circuit is safely isolated, proven dead, and you are trained/supervised.

**1. What is a Ceiling Rose?**
If you have never seen one, a ceiling rose is two things in one: a **junction point** where several cables join together, and the **connection point** for the lamp holder (the part the light hangs from). It is not just a connector; it is also where the circuit continues onward to the next light point, which is why it often looks crowded with wires.

**2. What 'Loop-in' Means**
A lighting circuit often goes from the consumer unit to Light 1, then Light 2, and so on. **Loop-in** means the main supply is joined at each ceiling rose and continues to the next one. At a typical rose in the middle of a run, you often see:
- a cable bringing supply **in**
- a cable taking supply **out** to the next light
- a cable going to the switch (the **switch drop**)

**3. The Three Plates (Terminal Groups)**
Think of a 3-plate rose as three separate labelled buckets:

1. **Plate A — Neutrals Group:** This is for all neutrals. It commonly includes Neutral from supply in, Neutral to supply out, and the lamp neutral. Neutral is normally **not** switched.

2. **Plate B — Permanent Lives (Loop):** This is the live join/group used to continue the supply and feed the switch. It commonly includes Live from supply in, Live to supply out, and the live feed down to the switch. This group would be live when the circuit is energised.

3. **Plate C — Switched Live:** This group is specifically for the power returning from the switch. It contains the switched live return and the lamp live connection. This group is only live when the switch is **ON**.

**4. The Role of the Switch (plain English)**
A 1-way switch acts like a bridge. In loop-in wiring, the switch has:
- a **feed down** from the Permanent Live (Loop) group
- a **return back** (switched live) to the Switched Live group

When the switch is ON, it lets power jump from the permanent live feed to the lamp.

**5. The Simple Wiring Map**
To keep it simple, remember these roles:
- **Neutrals:** supply in, supply out (if present), lamp neutral
- **Permanent lives (loop):** live in, live out (if present), feed to switch
- **Switched live:** return from switch, lamp live
- **CPC (earth):** all CPCs joined together and connected to the rose earth terminal/connector

questions.questionText: What are the two main functions of a ceiling rose?
questions.hint: It joins cables and provides the connection point for the light.

questions.questionText: Which terminal group would be live when the circuit is energised even if the light switch is OFF?
questions.hint: It's the group that feeds the switch and loops onward.

questions.questionText: Is the Neutral wire usually connected to the switch in a standard loop-in circuit?
questions.hint: In a basic loop-in circuit, the switch interrupts the live path.

questions.questionText: Why is the lamp's live wire kept in a separate terminal from the permanent live (loop) wires?
questions.expectedAnswer: So the switch can control it
questions.hint: If the lamp live was in the permanent live group, the lamp would be live all the time.

questions.questionText: In the middle of a loop-in circuit, list the three neutral roles you’d expect to be grouped together in the Neutral terminal (don’t worry about colours yet).
expectedAnswer: neutral in, neutral out, lamp neutral
supply neutral in, supply neutral out, lamp neutral
neutral from supply in, neutral to next light, neutral to lamp
questions.hint: Think: supply in, supply out (to next light), and the lamp connection.

questions.questionText: Which specific conductor returns from the switch to the ceiling rose to power the lamp when the switch is ON?
questions.hint: It becomes live only when the switch is ON.

questions.questionText: What is the name of the wiring method where the main supply continues from rose to rose (light point to light point)?
Explain why a ceiling rose at the end of a circuit (the last light) has fewer wires than one in the middle of a circuit. Which specific roles would be missing?
questions.expectedAnswer: The 'supply out to next light' live and neutral are missing because there is no next light to feed.
questions.hint: Think about what 'out' means when there is no next light.

content.title: Spaced Review (rose-relevant)

questions.questionText: In a standard 1-way lighting circuit, which conductor does the switch interrupt: Line (live) or Neutral?
questions.hint: The goal is that the lamp holder isn’t live when the switch is OFF.

questions.questionText: Name the three terminal groups in a 3-plate ceiling rose.
questions.hint: Think: neutrals bucket, always-live join, and switch-controlled return.

questions.questionText: In one sentence, what is the purpose of the CPC (earth) in a lighting circuit?
questions.expectedAnswer: To provide an earth path for fault current so protective devices can operate and keep exposed metal parts safe.
questions.hint: It’s a safety path, not part of normal current flow.

questions.questionText: Before opening/accessing a training rig accessory, what must be confirmed about the rig state?
questions.expectedAnswer: It is isolated and in an approved dead state (proven dead).
questions.hint: No work on live equipment—confirm dead first.

content.notes: Reinforcing the core ceiling rose mental model and rig-safe habits.
